paragraphs.paragraph: Dissolution of biological samples in deep eutectic solvents: An approach for extraction of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons followed by liquid chromatography-fluorescence detection
Zahra Helalat–Nezhad, Kamal Ghanemi ∗, Mehdi Fallah–Mehrjardi
Department of Marine Chemistry, Faculty of Marine Science, Khorramshahr University of Marine Science and Technology, P.O. BOX 669, Khorramshahr, Ir
a b s t r a c t

paragraphs.head: a r t i c l e i  n  f  o

paragraphs.paragraph:
Keywords:   
Deep eutectic solvent   
Choline chloride-oxalic acid   
Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs)   
Extraction   
Biological samples   
High performance liquid   
chromatography-fluorescence detection
paragraphs.head: a r t i c l e i  n  f  o

paragraphs.paragraph: A  novel sample  preparation method based  on  the  complete dissolution of  marine biological  samples in choline chloride-oxalic acid (ChCl-Ox) deep eutectic solvent was developed for fast and efficient extraction of  eight polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) using  minimum volumes  of  cyclohexane. The extracted PAHs were  purified and  then measured by  high-performance liquid chromatographyfluorescence detection (HPLC-FL). The  effect  of key  parameters on  extraction recoveries and  precision was investigated. At  optimized conditions, the  studied  samples were  dissolved under  atmospheric pressure in ChCl-Ox (1:2) at $5 5 ^ { \circ } C$ for $3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ , which is considerably lower than the temperature used in the classical and  current methods. After  dissolution, it  took  approximately $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ to  quantitatively extract the  PAHs  from  ChCl-Ox using $5 \mathrm { m L }$ cyclohexane. Depending on  the analyte, the developed method was linear over  the calibration range  1.0–250,  2.0–250,  and $5 . 0 { - } 2 5 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ ,  with $r ^ { 2 } > 0 . 9 9 6$ . The  detection limits of  the  method were  between 0.50  and $3 . 0 8 \mathrm { n g g } ^ { - 1 }$ .  The  intra-day and  inter-day precisions (based on the relative standard deviation, $n = 5$ )  of the  spiked  PAHs  at  a concentration level of $5 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ were  better than $1 2 . 6 \%$ and $1 3 . 3 \%$ , respectively. Individual PAH  recoveries from spiked  marine  fish  and  macroalgae samples were  in  the  range of $7 1 . 6 \%$ to $1 0 9 . 6 \%$ . For  comparison, the  spiked  samples were  also  subjected to the Soxhlet extraction method. The  simplicity of the procedure, high extraction efficiency, short  analysis time, and use of  safe  and inexpensive components suggest the  proposed method has a  high  potential for utilization in routine trace  PAH  analysis in biological samples.

paragraphs.paragraph: 1. Introduction
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: The increasing social demand for analytical methods and the need for fast, accurate, precise, selective, and sensitive methodologies oblige us to consider the use of reagents that are innocuous, or at least less toxic than those currently used. We  should also consider a drastic reduction in the amount of samples, reagents, and solvents employed for analysis, as well as to minimize, decontaminate, and neutralize the waste generated [1].
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: In nearly all analytical methods used for determining trace organic pollutants, sample preparation, especially involving extraction, occupies a strategic place [2]. This step generally extracts the target analytes from their matrices into solution and renders them suitable for analysis [1,2].
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a large group of organic compounds that are included in the European Union (EU) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) priority pollutant list because of their mutagenic and carcinogenic properties [3–6]. Most people are exposed to PAHs predominantly from dietary sources, especially seafood [7–9]. In the marine environment, PAHs are available biologically to marine species via the food chain, as waterborne compounds, and from contaminated sediments. As lipophilic compounds, they can easily cross lipid membranes and have the potential to accumulate in aquatic organisms, and may interfere in normal DNA functioning [3,10].
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: The mode of extraction for PAHs is highly dependent on the matrix. For solid-based matrices such as food samples, sediments, soil, and marine organisms, classical extraction methods such as Soxhlet extraction with nonpolar solvents are used [11]. This method utilizes large amounts of solvent as well as sample and is considerably time consuming [12]. Another separation protocol of PAHs from lipophilic products is based on saponification in basic alcoholic solution, a process that requires $2 { \cdot } 4 \mathrm { h }$ Moreover, the presence of alcohol in the hydrolytic mixture interferes with the alkylated PAH derivatives [10]. Consequently, current methods tend to minimize the consumption of solvents, sample amount, and extraction time with the aid of additional energy and/or pressure to the mixture of sample and solvent [13]. These methods, namely, microwave-assisted extraction (MAE) [14], supercritical fluid extraction (SFE) [15], pressurized liquid extraction (PLE) [16], and ultrasound-assisted extraction (USE) [17], differ in the way that the energy is supplied to the system and the kind of extracting fluid employed.
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: Recently, some methods have used microwaves in combination with water instead of organic solvents for extracting PAHs from solid matrices [18]. Although this technique can considerably increase the environmental-friendliness of the method, some target analytes, e.g., 5-ring PAHs, are fairly insoluble in water, leading to a very small amount extracted into the final organic solvent. Therefore, these analytes produce low signals that may just be detectable with highly sensitive instruments such as gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS).

An alternate approach for the extraction of analytes from biological samples is the use of ionic liquids (ILs). For example, Germán-Hernández and co-workers utilized aggregates of 1- hexadecyl-3-butyl imidazolium bromide in a focused-microwaveassisted extraction method followed by high-performance liquid chromatography with ultraviolet and fluorescence detection to determine the $1 5 + 1$ EU priority PAHs in toasted cereals [19].
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: The widespread use of ILs in both academia and industry is attributed to their unique combination of properties that include negligible vapor pressure, high thermal stability, low/no volatility, and ease of handling [20]. But typically, one cannot simply evaporate ILs to recover analytes, as analytical separations are generally performed with organic solvents. Many reports have also highlighted the hazardous nature and poor biodegradability of most ILs [21]. In addition, processes for the synthesis of ILs are not always environmentally friendly because they generally require large amount of salts and solvents for complete anion exchange [22].
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: To overcome the limitations of high price and toxicity of ILs, a new generation of green solvents—deep eutectic solvents (DESs)—have emerged [23]. A DES is generally composed of two or three non-toxic components that are capable of associating with each other through hydrogen bonds [22]. DESs typically have a very high depression in freezing point and are liquids at temperatures ranging from $2 1 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ to $7 0 ^ { \circ } C$ [23]. Choline chloride (ChCl), an inexpensive, biodegradable, and non-toxic quaternary ammonium salt, is widely used as one of the components in the formation of DESs [24]. When combined with non-toxic hydrogen bond donors (HBDs), such as carboxylic acids (e.g., oxalic acid), urea, or polyols (e.g., glycerol), ChCl is capable of rapidly forming a liquid [22–24]. These mixtures can be prepared with high purity and do not react with water, which allows for easy storage. In addition, they are biodegradable, biocompatible, non-toxic, non-flammable, and inexpensive [22]. Charge delocalization that is achieved through hydrogen bonding between the halide anion (e.g., $\mathbf { C l } ^ { - }$ in ChCl) with an HBD moiety is responsible for formation of the liquid [23].
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: Liquid ChCl mixtures have been used in applications in various fields, including drug solubilization [25], biodiesel purification [26], and electrodeposition of metals [23]. Moreover, they have been proven to dissolve macromolecules. For example, in 2013, Dai et al. [27] utilized different types of DESs composed of natural constituents, e.g., proline-malic acid (PMA), for the extraction of phenolic metabolites of various polarities from safflower. Most major phenolic compounds were recovered from the DES with yields between $7 5 \%$ and $9 7 \%$ . They also found that the H-bonding interactions between DES molecules and phenolic compounds are responsible for their high extractability.
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: Similarly, Bi and co-workers used alcohol-based DESs that are prepared by mixing ChCl with different alcohol-based HBDs to extract flavonoids (myricetin and amentoflavone) from plants [28].
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: We recently reported the application of some DESs for complete dissolution of marine biological samples, which facilitated the quantitative extraction of some studied metals with small volumes of dilute nitric acid for determination by flame atomic absorption spectrometry (FAAS) [29]. Therefore, based on these experiments, we  developed a new, green, and efficient method for the extraction of PAHs from marine biological samples, e.g., fish and macroalgae samples, after their complete dissolution in the studied DESs. The extracted PAHs were then analyzed with highperformance liquid chromatography coupled with a fluorescence detector. Generally, the chemical characteristics of PAHs are similar within a given ring number [30]; therefore, PAHs that contain three, four, and five aromatic rings were selected, because more than $80 \%$ of USEPA PAHs belong to these ring classes. As a model, 8 PAHs including phenanthrene (Ph), anthracene (An), fluoranthene (Flt), pyrene (Pyr), benz[a]anthracene (BaA), chrysene (Chry), benzo[e]pyrene (BeP), and benzo[a]pyrene (BaP) were studied. The optimum analytical conditions for quantitative recoveries of PAHs were investigated. To our knowledge, this is the first report of using DESs for the extraction of organic pollutants from solid-based biological matrices.
paragraphs.head: 1. Introduction

paragraphs.paragraph: 2. Experimental
paragraphs.head: 2. Experimental

paragraphs.paragraph: 2.1. Reagents and solutions
paragraphs.head: 2.1. Reagents and solutions

paragraphs.paragraph: All reagents used in the experiment were of analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. Choline chloride [ $\mathrm { ^ { \prime } C _ { 5 } H _ { 1 4 } N C l O }$ , $9 9 . 0 \%$ was purchased from Sigma (St. Louis, MO, USA). High-purity oxalic acid (Ox) was supplied by Merck (Darmstadt, Germany). The standard mixture of PAHs (Ph, An, Flt, Pyr, BaA, Chry, BeP, and BaP) containing $5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { g } \mathrm { m L } ^ { - 1 }$ of each component in toluene was purchased from Supelco (Bellefonte, PA, USA). Stock solutions containing $1 0 \mu \mathrm { g } \mathrm { m L } ^ { - 1 }$ of PAHs were prepared by dilution of the standard mixture in acetonitrile and stored at $4 ^ { \circ } C$ in darkness. Fresh calibration solutions were prepared daily from stock solutions. HPLC-grade acetonitrile, dichloromethane, $n$ -hexane, toluene, cyclohexane, and water were purchased from Merck. Double distilled deionized water was used throughout. All glassware was washed three times with $n$ -hexane and methanol before use.
paragraphs.head: 2.1. Reagents and solutions

paragraphs.paragraph: 2.2. Instrumentation
paragraphs.head: 2.2. Instrumentation

paragraphs.paragraph: PAHs were quantitatively determined with the Knauer HPLC instrument (Berlin, Germany) with a Wellchrom series solvent organizer (k-1500), binary pump (k-1001), vacuum degasser, electrical injection system, and RF-10 AXL fluorescence detector. The column temperature was maintained at $2 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C }$ in an oven (S-4000) with a thermostat. PAHs were separated on a Nucleosil® LC-PAH column $2 5 0 \mathrm { m m } \times 4 . 6 \mathrm { m m }$ i.d., particle size $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,  pore size $1 0 0 { \mathring { \mathsf { A } } } { \bmod { \mathsf { A } } }$ from Macherey-Nagel (Düren, Germany). A personal computer equipped with Ezchrom 3.1.7 software (Knauer) for the LC system was used to acquire and store the chromatographic data. A rotary evaporator (Heidolph Laborota 4011-digital, Germany) with bath temperature $\leq 3 0 ^ { \circ } C$ was used for the fast solvent evaporation of the extracts.
paragraphs.head: 2.2. Instrumentation

paragraphs.paragraph: 2.3. Sample collection and pretreatment
paragraphs.head: 2.3. Sample collection and pretreatment

paragraphs.paragraph: In this study, two types of marine fish samples i.e., Kafshak (Platichthys flesus) and Shoorideh (Otolithes ruber) were bought fresh from a local fish market in Khorramshahr, Iran. These fish are usually caught from the Musa estuary (north-western region of the Persian Gulf, Iran). They have a high demand and are widely consumed by the people in this region. To study extraction performance and optimize the extraction conditions as indicated in the individual experiments, an uncontaminated Hamour fish sample (Epinephelus coioides) was prepared at the marine fish research station (Bandar Emam Khomeini, Iran). All samples were kept cold in an icebox during transportation to the laboratory. At the laboratory, the fish samples were washed thoroughly with deionized water and the muscle tissues were separated and cut into small pieces. A marine macroalgae sample (Enteromorpha intestinalis) was collected from Bushehr (north of the Persian Gulf, Iran). All samples were freeze-dried for about $2 4 \mathrm { h }$ , and the dried samples were ground to fine powders and sieved through a 125 mesh.
paragraphs.head: 2.3. Sample collection and pretreatment

paragraphs.paragraph: 2.4. Preparation of spiked samples

To evaluate the extraction performance during the optimization and validation of the method, the spiking of the uncontaminated fish sample (previously checked to be PAH-free) was performed as follows: $_ { 1 \mathrm { g } }$ of the freeze-dried and powdered sample was mixed completely with $2 5 0 \mu \mathrm { L }$ of acetonitrile containing a known concentration of each PAH to get a desired concentration of analytes $( 5 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 } .$ ). The samples were then stored in the dark to dry. Then, all samples including non-spiked and spiked samples were preserved in pre-cleaned polyethylene bottles at $4 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ until the extraction was conducted.
paragraphs.head: 2.3. Sample collection and pretreatment

paragraphs.paragraph: 2.5. Preparation of eutectic mixtures
paragraphs.head: 2.5. Preparation of eutectic mixtures

paragraphs.paragraph: There is no limit to the number or type of DESs that can be prepared from available chemicals, because there are a large number of salts and hydrogen bond donors that can be used to prepare these solvent mixtures [31]. Amides, carboxylic acids, and alcohols are 3 major groups of HBDs that are widely used, in combination with ChCl, for producing DESs [23,24,31]. Our preliminary experiments indicated that ChCl-Ox DES systems have more ability to dissolve marine biological samples and extract the analytes from their matrices than other common eutectic solvents such as ChClurea and ChCl-glycerol. These findings are in coherence with those outlined in other studies. For example, in 2009, Morrison et al. [25] showed that $80 \%$ of the studied drugs are about 3 to 22,000 times more soluble in carboxylic-based DESs than in other types.
paragraphs.head: 2.5. Preparation of eutectic mixtures

paragraphs.paragraph: Therefore, in this work, the eutectic mixtures of ChCl-Ox were prepared at molar ratios of 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3, and utilized as solvents for the extraction of the PAHs from the biological samples. To prepare these mixtures, ChCl was mixed with $_ { 0 \mathrm { { x } } }$ in a $5 0 \mathrm { - m L }$ roundbottomed flask, which was then placed in a small water-bath, which was heated using a hot-plate stirrer. The temperature of the DES was continuously monitored with a thermometer $( \pm 0 . 1 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C } )$ , and the eutectic mixture was formed by stirring the two components together at $4 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C }$ until a homogeneous, colorless liquid was formed.
paragraphs.head: 2.5. Preparation of eutectic mixtures

paragraphs.paragraph: 2.6. Proposed eutectic-based extraction method
paragraphs.head: 2.6. Proposed eutectic-based extraction method

paragraphs.paragraph: Before beginning the procedure, the temperature of the studied DES was increased to $5 0 { - } 7 0 ^ { \circ } C $ and maintained at each studied temperature. Exactly $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ of the biological sample (fish or macroalgae) was added to a known volume $( 1 . 5 { - } 3 . 5 \mathrm { m L } )$ of ChClOx and stirred at $1 2 0 \mathrm { r p m }$ for a specified time interval $( 2 0 { - } 7 0 \operatorname * { m i n } )$ . During this stage, the entire sample was dissolved, and a relatively uniform solution was obtained. Then, known volumes of extracting solvent were added and stirred for 20–60 min. The supernatant solution was completely separated, and passed through a column of $0 . 3 { \mathrm { g } }$ silica gel; the column was then washed with $5 \mathrm { m L }$ of cyclohexane; the collected solvents were evaporated in the rotary evaporator at $3 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C }$ until almost dry (about $3 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ ). The sample was then diluted with $1 . 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of acetonitrile and passed through a $0 . 2 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ PTFE filter (Macherey-Nagel) to prevent any suspended particles from entering into the HPLC column. Finally, the solution was injected into the HPLC-FL system for analysis. The extractions were repeated in triplicate $( n = 3 )$ . With each series of extractions, a similar blank procedure was also conducted without any sample material. After optimization, this method was applied to determine the prevalence of the PAHs in different fish and macroalgae samples.
paragraphs.head: 2.6. Proposed eutectic-based extraction method

paragraphs.paragraph: 2.7. Liquid chromatographic condition

All sample injections were held constant at $2 0 \mu \mathrm { L }$ through the use of a fixed-volume injection loop. The flow rate of the mobile phase (A) acetonitrile and (B) water was set at $1 . 0 \mathrm { m L } \mathrm { m i n } ^ { - 1 }$ . The PAHs were separated using the following gradient program: $65 \%$ A was maintained for $2 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ , a linear gradient was used from $6 5 \%$ A at $2 \mathrm { m i n }$ to $100 \%$ A at $1 4 \mathrm { m i n }$ , and $100 \%$ A was maintained for $1 0 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ . Thereafter, the mobile phase was returned to the initial condition $( 3 5 \% \mathrm { A } )$ and held for $5 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ to prepare the column for the next injection. The column temperature was maintained at $2 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C$ The chromatographic data were acquired at the following excitation/emission wavelengths: $2 5 0 / 3 7 5 \mathrm { n m }$ (Ph, An), $2 3 7 / 4 4 0 \mathrm { n m }$ (Flt), 270/376 nm (Pyr), $3 3 0 / 4 1 0 \mathrm { n m }$ (BaA, Chry, and BeP), and $3 8 4 / 4 1 0 \mathrm { n m }$ (BaP). It was possible to simultaneously monitor 5 ex/em pairs, hence only one injection was required for the analysis. The quantitative analysis of individual PAHs in the samples was carried out by comparing the peak areas of the individual PAHs with the peak areas of the PAHs in the standard mixture.
paragraphs.head: 2.6. Proposed eutectic-based extraction method

paragraphs.paragraph: 2.8. Soxhlet extraction method
paragraphs.head: 2.8. Soxhlet extraction method

paragraphs.paragraph: According the procedure described by S. Mora et al. [32], two grams of the spiked sample was extracted using Soxhlet for $^ { 8 \mathrm { h } }$ with $2 5 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of methanol. The extracts were then saponified by adding $2 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of $0 . 7  { \mathrm { M } }  { }  { \mathrm { K O H } }$ and $3 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of water and refluxing for $2 \mathrm { h }$ . The resulting mixture was transferred into a separating funnel and extracted 3 times with $n$ -hexane (once with ${ \mathfrak { g o m L } }$ , twice with $5 0 \mathrm { m L }$ ). Then the extracts were combined, filtered through glass wool and dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate. The extracts were concentrated by rotary evaporation down to $5 \mathrm { m L }$ . Finally, the extract was cleaned up and fractionated by passing it through a silica/alumina column. Elution was performed using $2 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of $n$ -hexane to yield the first fraction (containing the aliphatic hydrocarbons), then $3 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of $n$ -hexane: dichloromethane (90:10) and followed by $2 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of $n$ -hexane: dichloromethane (50:50). These two eluents containing the aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) were combined, rotary evaporated to near dryness and finally diluted in $1 \mathrm { m L }$ acetonitrile for HPLC-FL analysis.
paragraphs.head: 2.8. Soxhlet extraction method

paragraphs.paragraph: 3. Results and discussion
paragraphs.head: 3. Results and discussion

paragraphs.paragraph: To achieve maximum efficiency, the effect of experimental variables such as the type and volume of DES, dissolution time and temperature, amount of sample, type and volume of extracting solvent, and extraction time were investigated and optimized. These parameters control the dissolution of biological samples in DESs and the extraction of PAHs from their matrices.
paragraphs.head: 3. Results and discussion

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.1. Optimizing the dissolution and extraction parameters
paragraphs.head: 3.1. Optimizing the dissolution and extraction parameters

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.1.1. Effect of the type and composition of DES
paragraphs.head: 3.1.1. Effect of the type and composition of DES

paragraphs.paragraph: DESs are a unique class of multi-component solvent systems with varying physico-chemical properties [22,23]. To facilitate the extraction of PAHs from their matrices to organic solvent, it was necessary to completely dissolve the biological sample in an appropriate DES. Changing the type and/or the composition of the DES can significantly impact the sample dissolution and efficient extraction of analytes from their matrices. In this experiment, ChCl was mixed separately with $_ { 0 \mathrm { { x } } }$ , at 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3 (ChCl: Ox) molar ratios. Then, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ of the spiked sample was added to $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ of each DES under investigation and the procedure conducted as stated in Section 2.6. As can be seen in Fig. 1, the best extraction recoveries over the range $7 3 . 4 \substack { - 1 0 2 . 0 \% }$ were obtained when the spiked sample was completely dissolved in ChCl: Ox (1:2). At 1:1 and 1:3 ChCl: Ox molar ratios, the extraction recoveries of all PAHs did not exceed $9 3 . 3 \%$ and $7 9 . 4 \%$ , respectively.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.1. Effect of the type and composition of DES

Conditions: volume of $\mathbf { C h C l : O x } , 2 . 5 \mathbf { m L }$ ; dissolution temperature, $5 5 ^ { \circ } C$ ; dissolution time, $3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ ; amount of sample, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ ; volume of cyclohexane, $5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; extraction time, $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ .

paragraphs.head: Fig. 2
paragraph: Fig. 2. Effect of the volume of ChCl:Ox (1:2) on the recovery of PAHs. Conditions: dissolution temperature, $5 5 ^ { \circ } C$ ; dissolution time, $3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ ; amount of sample, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ ; volume of cyclohexane, $5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; extraction time, $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ .

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.1.2. Effect of the volume of ChCl-Ox

The volume of ChCl-Ox has a significant effect on the dissolution of the biological samples and its constituents. Different volumes $( 1 . 5 \mathrm { - } 3 . 5 \mathrm { m L } )$ of ChCl-Ox (1:2) were added to $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ of the spiked sample and the samples were processed according to the general procedure.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.1. Effect of the type and composition of DES

paragraphs.paragraph: As can be seen in Fig. 2, when the volume of ChCl-Ox (1:2) increased from 1.5 to $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ , the extraction efficiencies increased rapidly, and with $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ of ChCl-Ox (1:2), about $7 8 . 5 \substack { - 1 0 1 . 1 \% }$ of PAHs were extracted into the organic solvent; this trend was relatively constant up to $3 . 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of ChCl-Ox (1:2). However, when the ChCl-Ox (1:2) volume was increased to $3 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ , the extraction efficiency of all studied PAHs decreased slightly, compared to $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ of ChCl-Ox (1:2). The volume of organic solvent used for extracting PAHs from 1.5 to $3 . 0 \mathrm { m L }$ of ChCl-Ox was sufficient, but this could not extract completely all PAHs from larger volumes of ChClOx, because of incomplete mixing of the organic solvent with the dissolved biological sample and the studied DES. This indicated that $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ was the optimum volume of ChCl-Ox (1:2), which was adopted in subsequent tests. Lower volumes of ChCl- $. 0 \mathbf { x }$ (1:2) were insufficient for complete dissolution of the biological samples and led to lower extraction efficiency and precision.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.1. Effect of the type and composition of DES
Fig. 3
paragraph: Fig. 3. Effect of the dissolution temperature on the recovery of PAHs. Conditions: volume of ChCl:Ox (1:2), $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ dissolution time, $3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ ; amount of sample, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ ; volume of cyclohexane, $5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; extraction time, $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ .

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.1.3. Effect of dissolution temperature

Temperature can influence several physico-chemical properties of a eutectic-based solvent such as viscosity, surface tension, diffusivity, conductivity, and heat capacity [33]. Increasing temperature generally reduces the viscosity and the surface tension of a DES and increases the diffusivity of the solvent, which can facilitate the penetration of DES in the matrices of the sample, leading to more breaking down of the intermolecular bonds, and therefore enhancing their solubility [28]. In this work, the effect of increasing temperature on the solubility and extraction of PAHs from their matrices was studied over the range $5 0 { - } 7 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C .$ As can be seen in Fig. 3, the best extraction recoveries of $7 6 . 2 \substack { - 1 1 3 . 5 \% }$ for all studied PAHs were obtained when the temperature was held between $5 5 \mathrm { - } 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C } .$ At temperatures greater than $6 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C ,$ the extraction recoveries of both the 3- and 4-ring PAHs were rapidly reduced, but the extraction recoveries of the 5-ring PAHs reached $6 4 . 8 \substack { - 7 4 . 9 \% }$ . This effect may be related to the more evaporation of the $3 -$ and 4-ring PAHs at higher temperatures, because of their inherently higher vapor pressure, compared to the 5-ring PAHs. At temperatures lower than $5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathsf C ,$ the dissolution of the sample in ChCl-Ox (1:2) was incomplete and led to relatively low extraction recoveries, for some PAHs. Therefore, to obtain quantitative and precise results, the temperature of the ChCl-Ox was set at $5 5 ^ { \circ } \mathsf { C }$ Compared to microwave-assisted and accelerated extraction methods, this method can proceed successfully at relatively lower temperatures and at atmospheric pressure [34–36].
paragraphs.head: 3.1.1. Effect of the type and composition of DES

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.1.4. Effect of extraction conditions
paragraphs.head: 3.1.4. Effect of extraction conditions

paragraphs.paragraph: Depending on the extraction technique and type of sample matrix, various organic solvents have been used for the extraction of PAHs [37,38]. The nature of the solvent is of prime importance and should meet three criteria: efficiency, selectivity, and compatibility. Therefore, the following considerations should be taken into account when selecting an appropriate solvent for efficient extraction of PAHs. First of all, PAHs should have high solubility in the solvent. Secondly, the solvent should be immiscible or have low solubility in DESs to minimize the loss of solvent in the eutectic-based solution. Thirdly, the solvent should have low vapor pressure to prevent evaporative loss during extraction. Based on these criteria, and from our own experience and literature reports, four organic solvents, dichloromethane, toluene, cyclohexane, and $n$ -hexane were studied. Fig. 4 shows that the best recoveries $( 7 2 \% - 1 1 0 \% )$ of all PAHs were achieved using cyclohexane and dichloromethane for extraction. Solvents such as $n$ -hexane and toluene provided recoveries in the range of $4 1 \% - 9 6 \%$ . However, cyclohexane was more selective than dichloromethane for extraction of PAHs, since dichloromethane extracted larger amounts of lipids that were soluble and/or turn to solid at room temperature and then partly co-eluted with PAHs during the cleanup stage. These results are in accordance with previous reports [5,34–37]. Therefore, cyclohexane was selected as a proper extracting solvent.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.4. Effect of extraction conditions
Fig. 4
paragraph: Fig. 4. Effect of the type of extracting solvent on the recovery of PAHs. Conditions: volume of ChCl:Ox (1:2), $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; dissolution temperature, $5 5 ^ { \circ } C$ ; dissolution time, $3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ ; amount of sample, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ ; extraction time, $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ .

paragraphs.head: Fig. 5
paragraph: Fig. 5. Effect of the extraction time on the recovery of PAHs. Conditions: volume of ChCl:Ox (1:2), $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; dissolution temperature, $5 5 ^ { \circ } C$ ; dissolution time, $3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ ; amount of sample, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ ; volume of cyclohexane, $5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; extraction time, $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ .

paragraphs.paragraph: Next, the time required for extracting the analytes from the dissolved sample (in ChCl-Ox) to the organic solvent (cyclohexane) was studied over the range of $5 { - } 3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ . As can be seen in Fig. 5, after 5 min of solvent extraction, the recoveries of the 3- and 4-ring PAHs were in the range of 26.3 to $4 7 . 4 \%$ and the extraction efficiencies of the 5-ring PAHs were around $8 2 . 0 \%$ . By increasing the extraction time, the extraction recoveries of all PAHs were increased, and reached maximum levels $( 8 0 . 7 - 1 1 5 . 8 \% )$ at $2 0 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ . At higher extraction times, a small decrease in the extraction of all PAHs was observed, and therefore the optimum extraction time was set at $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ .

The volume of the organic solvent is the next important issue that was carefully studied in the range of 2.5 to $2 0 \mathrm { m L }$ . The results are depicted in Fig. 6. As shown, using just $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ of cyclohexane can extract PAHs over the range of 54.4 to $7 7 . 5 \%$ . By increasing the volume of the extracting solvent to $5 \mathrm { m L }$ , the recoveries were also increased and ranged between 85.2 to $1 0 8 . 7 \%$ . This trend did not change considerably up to $1 0 \mathrm { m L }$ . Therefore, to reduce the consumption of the organic solvent, the extraction volume of $5 \mathrm { m L }$ was selected as the optimum value.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.4. Effect of extraction conditions

paragraphs.paragraph: As reported, the consumption of organic solvents in the proposed method is very low, guaranteeing safety of operators and the environment. In addition, because of the quick dissolution of the studied biological samples in ChCl-Ox, the quantitative extraction of PAHs can be done within a reasonable amount of time and without using any apparatus like ultrasonic and microwave generators.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.4. Effect of extraction conditions
Fig. 6
paragraph: Fig. 6. Effect of the volume of cyclohexane on the recovery of PAHs. Conditions: volume of ChCl:Ox (1:2), $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; dissolution temperature, $5 5 ^ { \circ } C$ ; dissolution time, $3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ ; amount of sample, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ ; extraction time, $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ .

paragraphs.head: Fig. 7
paragraph: Fig. 7. Effect of the dissolution time on the recovery of PAHs. Conditions: volume of ChCl:Ox (1:2), $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; dissolution temperature, $5 5 ^ { \circ } C$ ; amount of sample, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ volume of cyclohexane, $5 \mathrm { m L }$ ; extraction time, $2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ .

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.1.5. Effect of the dissolution time

Depending on the temperature and type of the DES and analyte, varying time intervals between 25 to 60 min have been reported for the dissolution of biological samples and extraction of their ingredients [27,28,38]. The dissolution time of the sample in ChCl-Ox (1:2) is an important issue that can influence the extraction recoveries of PAHs. Therefore, the effect of the dissolution time on the extraction was studied at five time intervals between 20–60 min. According to the results presented in Fig. 7, the extraction recoveries of all PAHs increased as the dissolution time of the sample in ChCl-Ox (1:2) was increased from 20 to $4 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ . The best results (recoveries and precisions) for all PAHs was obtained when the sample was completely dissolved in ChCl-Ox (1:2) within $3 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ , therefore this time was selected as the optimum dissolution time. However, above 40 min, about 20 to $6 5 \%$ decrease for the extraction of the 3- and 4-ring PAHs was observed, compared to the maximum recoveries. In contrast, only up to $3 5 \%$ decrease in the recoveries of the 5-ring PAHs was reported, and the results were still repeatable. This trend may be related to slight evaporation of studied PAHs due to heating for longer times after the complete dissolution of the sample in the eutectic solvent.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.4. Effect of extraction conditions

paragraphs.paragraph: The time, on average, required for dissolution in ChCl-Ox and quantitative extraction of PAHs is comparable to that (about $3 0 \mathrm { m i n } \dot { . }$ ) in the MAE and PLE methods, without applying high pressures or sophisticated technologies to accelerate the extraction process [18,34,36]. This represents a high potential of the eutecticbased green solvents for use in different extraction technologies.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.4. Effect of extraction conditions
Table  1
paragraph: Table  1 Analytical performance of the proposed method at optimized conditions.

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.1.6. Effect of the amount of sample
paragraphs.head: 3.1.6. Effect of the amount of sample

paragraphs.paragraph: The effect of the amount of sample that can be dissolved in $2 . 5 \mathrm { m L }$ ChCl-Ox was studied at 0.10, 0.15, and $0 . 2 0 { \mathrm { g } } ,$ using the previously determined optimized conditions. Before analysis, the samples were spiked with a constant amount $( 1 0 \mathrm { n g } )$ of each PAH. It was found that with increasing the amount of the sample, the extraction recovery of all PAHs gradually decreased, and the highest extraction recoveries can be obtained with $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ of the sample. Therefore, $0 . 1 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ of the fish or macroalgae sample was used throughout.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.6. Effect of the amount of sample

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.1.7. Cleanup stage
paragraphs.head: 3.1.7. Cleanup stage

paragraphs.paragraph: Extracts from foods, biological, and environmental matrices contain not only the hydrophobic analytes of interest but also several other hydrophobic compounds, frequently lipids. These coextracted components not only interfere with the analytes but also frequently affect or damage the chromatographic column, decreasing its useful life and deteriorating the chromatographic system performance [5]. Among the several cleaning procedures developed for PAHs extracts, those based on solid-phase extraction are the most convenient in practice.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.7. Cleanup stage

paragraphs.paragraph: In this experiment, $0 . 3 0 { \mathrm { g } }$ of florisil and/or silica gel was used for cleanup of the extracted PAHs. After passing all the extracted solvent $( 5 \mathrm { m L } )$ through the sorbent, the column was washed with $5 \mathrm { m L }$ of cyclohexane. The collected solvents were evaporated in the rotary evaporator, and the steps were followed as described in the general procedure. However, both the sorbents gave the same results for the 3- and 4-ring PAHs, but the extraction recoveries of the 5-ring PAHs obtained by the silica gel were up to $7 . 0 \%$ higher than those using florisil. Therefore, the silica gel was selected as the appropriate sorbent for cleaning up the extracts. The same trend was observed by Pena et al. [5] during cleaning up the PAHs extracts obtained from fish samples, after applying MAE.
paragraphs.head: 3.1.7. Cleanup stage

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.2. Analytical performance
paragraphs.head: 3.2. Analytical performance

paragraphs.paragraph: Optimized experimental conditions were employed to validate the analytical performance of the proposed method. The results are summarized in Table 1. The linearity of the calibration plots based on the analyte peak areas was obtained between 1.0–250, 2.0–250, and $5 . 0 { - } 2 5 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ , depending on the analytes, with satisfactory coefficients of determination $( r ^ { 2 } )$ ranging between 0.9960 and 0.9997.
paragraphs.head: 3.2. Analytical performance

paragraphs.paragraph: Limits of detection (LODs) of the method, based on a signal-tonoise ratio of 3, were in the range of $0 . 5 0 { - } 3 . 0 8 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ . The limit of quantification (LOQ), which is defined as a signal-to-noise ratio of 10:1, was obtained in the range of $0 . 8 5 { - } 4 . 0 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ .
paragraphs.head: 3.2. Analytical performance

paragraphs.paragraph: The intra-day and inter-day precisions (5 days) of the spiked PAHs at concentration levels of $5 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ were evaluated by calculating the relative standard deviations (RSD) of 5 replicate runs of the proposed procedure. The intra-day precisions were in the range of $3 . 9 \mathrm { - } 2 . 6 \%$ , showing good repeatability of the method. The inter-day precisions based on replications at 5 different days were in the range of $4 . 0 \substack { - 1 3 . 3 \% }$ .
paragraphs.head: 3.2. Analytical performance
Fig. 8
paragraph: Fig. 8. Comparison of the Soxhlet method and the proposed method.

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.3. Comparison

The Soxhlet extraction technique has been commonly used as a benchmark technique in the extraction of PAHs from environmental samples [36]. Therefore, the extraction recovery of the proposed method was compared with the data obtained by Soxhlet extraction. To do this, the biological sample spiked with $5 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ of each PAH was subjected separately to the Soxhlet procedure and the proposed method. The results are summarized in Fig. 8, based on 3 replications. It can be clearly seen that the performance of the current method is considerably higher than that of the Soxhlet method. The observations (Fig. 8) show that the eutectic solvent is a key factor in the efficient dissolution of the total sample, which then facilitated the fast extraction of the analytes from their matrices to the organic solvent. All these facts indicate that in addition to saving time and energy as well as considerably low consumption of organic solvent, higher extraction recoveries can also be obtained by the proposed method, compared to Soxhlet extraction.
paragraphs.head: 3.2. Analytical performance

paragraphs.paragraph: The extraction results obtained are also comparable with some recent extraction methods like matrix solid-phase dispersion [39], ultrasonication extraction coupled with magnetic solid-phase clean-up [6], homogeneous liquid–liquid extraction [40], and acid-induced cloud point extraction [41]. However, this ChCl-Ox extraction method has demonstrated a particular advantage in the overall volume of organic solvent, which was much less than those of the above-mentioned procedures. Additionally, because of the complete dissolution of the sample in ChCl-Ox, the studied PAHs can be extracted quickly, without exposure to high temperatures and pressures like that applied in the routine extraction methods such as MAE and PLE.

paragraphs.paragraph: 3.4. Analysis of macroalgae and fish samples
paragraphs.head: 3.4. Analysis of macroalgae and fish samples

paragraphs.paragraph: The practical utility of the proposed method was evaluated by the determination of PAHs in marine biological samples (i.e., fish muscle and macroalgae), collected from different sites of the Persian Gulf. The muscles of two kinds of marine fish samples, including Kafshak (P. flesus) and Shoorideh (O. ruber) as well as the marine macroalgae (E. intentinalis) were selected for study using this method. After pre-treatment, each sample was subjected to the proposed procedure, under optimal conditions. Additionally, each sample was spiked with $5 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ of PAH, and the recoveries of extraction as well as the precisions (RSDs, $\mathrm { n } = 5$ ) were calculated and summarized in Table 2. The extraction recoveries of the spiked samples ranged from $7 0 . 0 \%$ to $1 0 9 . 6 \%$ , with RSDs of below $1 1 . 7 \%$ . As can be seen, the concentration of Ph in all samples is considerably higher than other PAHs. Similarly, S. de Mora et al. [32] pointed out the considerably high concentrations of $\mathrm { P h }$ in water, sediment, and fish samples collected from the north of the Persian Gulf. In Fig. 9, the HPLC-FL chromatograms of the extracted PAHs from the spiked (at $5 0 \mathrm { n g } \mathrm { g } ^ { - 1 }$ ) and non-spiked samples of a fish muscle of O. ruber are presented. Since the concentration of Ph was relatively high, the other studied PAHs were not clearly observed in the nonspiked chromatogram, but each of PAHs was detected by HLPC-FL. All these facts demonstrate that this new ChCl-Ox extraction procedure has a great potential for application to genuine environmental samples.
paragraphs.head: 3.4. Analysis of macroalgae and fish samples

paragraphs.paragraph: 4. Conclusion
paragraphs.head: 4. Conclusion

paragraphs.paragraph: Deep eutectic solvents are a new class of green solvents that have recently gained high utility in various fields such as separation, dissolution, and extraction. In the present work, a novel extraction technique based on the complete dissolution of marine biological samples in ChCl-Ox deep eutectic solvent was developed for convenient and quantitative extraction of PAHs. The extracted PAHs were then determined with HPLC-FL. This method provides some operational advantages such as simplicity of experimental procedure, use of low-cost eutectic solvent, relatively high-speed sample preparation, consumption of low amount of sample, and low organic solvent usage. Thus, this method demonstrates potential for routine trace PAH analysis in biological samples. Compared to routine extraction methods, such as MAE and PLE, the process of dissolution and extraction of PAHs can be conducted at relatively lower temperatures at atmospheric pressure. Under the most favorable conditions, the developed method exhibited particularly good limits of detection, linearity, and satisfactory repeatability. Overall, this study demonstrated that the proposed method is an efficient approach for the sample preparation of marine biological samples such as fish muscle and macralgae. This new approach opens an interesting and innovative way in the field of sample preparation methods for effectively handling complex samples.

abstracts: A novel sample preparation method based on the complete dissolution of marine biological samples in choline chloride-oxalic acid (ChCl-Ox) deep eutectic solvent was developed for fast and efficient extraction of eight polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) using minimum volumes of cyclohexane. The extracted PAHs were purified and then measured by high-performance liquid chromatographyfluorescence detection (HPLC-FL). The effect of key parameters on extraction recoveries and precision was investigated. At optimized conditions, the studied samples were dissolved under atmospheric pressure in ChCl-Ox (1:2) at 55 • C for 30 min, which is considerably lower than the temperature used in the classical and current methods. After dissolution, it took approximately 20 min to quantitatively extract the PAHs from ChCl-Ox using 5 mL cyclohexane. Depending on the analyte, the developed method was linear over the calibration range 1.0-250, 2.0-250, and 5.0-250 ng g -1 , with r 2 > 0.996. The detection limits of the method were between 0.50 and 3.08 ng g -1 . The intra-day and inter-day precisions (based on the relative standard deviation, n = 5) of the spiked PAHs at a concentration level of 50 ng g -1 were better than 12.6% and 13.3%, respectively. Individual PAH recoveries from spiked marine fish and macroalgae samples were in the range of 71.6% to 109.6%. For comparison, the spiked samples were also subjected to the Soxhlet extraction method. The simplicity of the procedure, high extraction efficiency, short analysis time, and use of safe and inexpensive components suggest the proposed method has a high potential for utilization in routine trace PAH analysis in biological samples.
